Ignore my steam hours played - I owned this game since very early access via the Microsoft store, back when it was a very basic (and yet already brilliant) walking survival sim and only mystery lake in a basic form existed. Every year I spend HOURS surviving in the wilderness playing over, and over again. It's the best survival game, the tensions of will i get caught in a storm, what if there is a wolf around the next corner, where can i find shelter to start a fire and warm up are what make this game great, it truly feels like real survival and real (gentle) anxiety over how to manage. Honestly it's brilliant. I think we've easily been playing it as a household for 10+ years and I think i'll always bring it out for wintertime, though I now know the maps too well and it's perhaps a little less tension building when i can find my way around in a white-out. 
This steam version was purchased recently so that, using a mod, my husband and I can multiplayer the game something we've always wanted. (which is less good than solo survival due to the mod hiccups but better than waiting for blackfrost to launch)
We love this so much that blackfrost (TLD2) will be a day one purchase. 

If you like survival games, this is the best one out there. If you like wintery games for some seasonal immersion, this is the game. From a tiny start up idea such a wonderful game (and add ons) has grown! Really worth it.
*I dont know why steam has wintermute separate to the main game, but my microsoft version has them combined (perks of early access purchase i guess!) it's an enjoyable dlc (second draft with the passenger plane much better than when they first released it) but the base game is where the gold and hundreds of hours to sink lies.*

The maps are enormous. The more you play, the more you discover how to use resources intelligently, learning to build caches and storage areas. There's so much to explore. I only play in survival mode, and the sole objective is to survive as long as possible without a time limit. It's great for learning skills one by one and discovering all the possibilities. I've played 33 hours so far and have only completed two maps, the easiest ones. This world is huge. The reality of survival is impressive and makes the game more challenging. You can die from illness, injury, cold, fatigue, dehydration, or hunger. The more you carry, the heavier you are, increasing your risk of injury and making you tire quickly. You must cook meat and boil water to avoid getting sick. There are antibiotics, painkillers, disinfectants, and so on. It's impossible to make a fire if the wind is too strong, and being in a blizzard kills quickly. Animals can attack you and you can hunt them for their skin and meat.   If you like realistic survival games without zombies or anything like that, this is the perfect game in my opinion.

The Long Dark is one of the most atmospheric and emotional survival games ever made — not because of jump scares or nonstop action, but because the world itself quietly tries to kill you. There are no zombies, no mutants, no enemies beyond wildlife and the cold. It’s just you, silence, and the constant need to make smart choices if you want to see another sunrise.

What makes it stand out is how grounded it feels. Every decision matters: how much food you carry, whether you risk traveling during a blizzard, if you should light a fire now or save the matches for later. The game forces patience and respect for nature, and the slower pace actually becomes one of its strengths — every success feels earned, and every mistake can be fatal.

The art style is beautiful in a minimalistic, hand-painted way, and the sound design — distant winds, cracking ice, and the terrifying howl of a wolf — creates a lonely but immersive atmosphere. Story mode has emotional weight and strong characters, while survival mode is a pure open sandbox where every run feels different.

The game isn’t about power fantasies — it’s about endurance, awareness, and learning from failure. Sometimes the harshness can feel unforgiving, but that’s exactly what makes surviving even a single night feel meaningful.

If you enjoy slow, thoughtful survival experiences that reward planning, immersion, and patience, The Long Dark is an unforgettable journey — harsh, beautiful, and one of the best pure survival games ever made.

The Long Dark is one of those rare survival games that feels both meditative and merciless. From the moment the plane crashes in the frozen Canadian wilderness, the experience grips the player with its quiet intensity. The gameplay focuses on realism rather than fast-paced action—there are no zombies or over-the-top weapons here. Instead, survival depends on managing body temperature, calorie intake, fatigue, and resource scarcity. Every decision, from when to light a fire to whether to risk crossing a frozen lake, feels crucial.

Visually, the game is stunning. The art style combines painterly environments with minimalist textures, creating an atmosphere that feels both harsh and beautiful. Snow-covered forests, abandoned cabins, and distant mountain ranges are rendered with striking simplicity. The soundscape complements this perfectly—gentle gusts of wind, the crunch of snow underfoot, and the distant howl of wolves all deepen the sense of isolation.

The storyline, especially in the episodic Wintermute campaign, adds emotional depth to the survival experience. It follows characters driven by loss, hope, and resilience, blending personal drama with environmental storytelling. Even in Sandbox mode, the world tells countless subtle stories through notes, remnants, and locations left behind.

Overall, The Long Dark blends survival mechanics with a hauntingly realistic portrayal of nature’s indifference and human endurance. It’s a game that rewards patience, reflection, and careful thought—a truly immersive testament to the beauty and brutality of the north.

That should be a good thing, but, when you discover how your time investment of 100 hrs here, 50 hrs there, can be permanently lost in an instant because of the deliberately confusing and ambiguous UI design, you'll feel betrayed. Shame on the developers.

Myself and others have lost 100+ hr runs because of the UI design. The UI does NOT inform you of what kinds of afflictions/debuffs that you have, even imminently lethal ones. This information is hidden inside of the menus. So, unless you remember to deliberately make the choice to open the menu to find out whether or not you might be dying (yes, even when your health bar is completely full, you can die in a single mouse click), it's on you to decide to access the menu or not, in order to discover that you're in danger of losing everything. Yes, the UI does not inform you that you could die in the next mouse click. Surprise! Permadeath, 100+ hrs of work deleted in an instant. 

It's your fault, silly. Tsk tsk, you should've been checking the menus!

The game lets you "pass time" and also "go to sleep" while you're bleeding out, and also while you have lacerations, which are wounds that re-open in your sleep. Because there are NO visual indicators on the UI that you're bleeding out, or wounded, you can literally kill yourself by passing time or going to sleep. You did it! It was your choice to unalive yourself, silly! 

The UI is completely bare except for an almost perpetual (always-on, meaningless boy-cried-wolf type of alert[!], for all non-ideal states, such as having the mere risk of potentially getting hypothermia... erm, this goes without saying, it's freaking cold out there). 

I lost 80 hrs of work on Stalker difficulty because I went to sleep for 2 hrs with blood loss, which I did, because.. I didn't know I had blood loss. Nothing on the UI warned me about it.

Continuing with this, it also lets you make the choice to pass time and go to sleep while you're freezing to death, or close to predators. I lost a 70-hr run on the easier Voyageur difficulty because I slept outside in the same area as a (confirmed) single wolf, but a wolf that I had just shot twice in the head with a revolver, and then when struggling with it, stabbed with my knife. I have put 150 hours into the game, which is saying something - time slips away because every decision matters. It's your fault, silly. Tsk tsk, you should've been checking the menus!

The game lets you "pass time" and also "go to sleep" while you're bleeding out, and also while you have lacerations, which are wounds that re-open in your sleep. Because there are NO visual indicators on the UI that you're bleeding out, or wounded, you can literally kill yourself by passing time or going to sleep. You did it! It was your choice to unalive yourself, silly! 

The UI is completely bare except for an almost perpetual (always-on, meaningless boy-cried-wolf type of alert[!], for all non-ideal states, such as having the mere risk of potentially getting hypothermia... erm, this goes without saying, it's freaking cold out there). 

I lost 80 hrs of work on Stalker difficulty because I went to sleep for 2 hrs with blood loss, which I did, because.. I didn't know I had blood loss. Nothing on the UI warned me about it.

Continuing with this, it also lets you make the choice to pass time and go to sleep while you're freezing to death, or close to predators. I lost a 70-hr run on the easier Voyageur difficulty because I slept outside in the same area as a (confirmed) single wolf, but a wolf that I had just shot twice in the head with a revolver, and then when struggling with it, stabbed with my knife. It ran away, tail between its legs, yelping, bleeding out, guaranteed to die within 2-3 minutes. Yet, it somehow went over to me and killed me in my sleep before its demise. I've also had shorter runs lost because of this sleeping mechanic as well, sleeping while it's warm, even bundled up, inside, literally in shelter, only for the weather to rapidly change to freezing, and then kill me in my sleep. 

This actually sounds thrilling, right? Going to sleep is the scariest gamble you could do, right?Well, the game forces you to sleep to stay alive, so no, this is simply disrespectful to the player.

For those that don't know - the game saves instantly as things happen, and your saves are instantly deleted as you're dying, not afterward. It's truly brutal. You can't even Alt+F4 to save yourself.

Why would I start over again, spend another 100 hours, only to lose everything when I decide to go to sleep? You've gotta be insane. The Long Dark - after 150 hours, you'll find out that the scariest, most dangerous thing in the treacherous, barren, icy, -60°F Canadian wilderness, filled to the brim with wolves, bears, and cougars, is your very own plush, down-filled sleeping bag.

事件核心——一场毫无必要的“技术跃进”

Yes, this game is a work of art, but it absolutely, 100%, in every way, will disrespect your time and then gaslight you. 

I have put 150 hours into the game, which is saying something - time slips away because every decision matters. That should be a good thing, but, when you discover how your time investment of 100 hrs here, 50 hrs there, can be permanently lost in an instant because of the deliberately confusing and ambiguous UI design, you'll feel betrayed. Shame on the developers.

Myself and others have lost 100+ hr runs because of the UI design. The UI does NOT inform you of what kinds of afflictions/debuffs that you have, even imminently lethal ones. This information is hidden inside of the menus. So, unless you remember to deliberately make the choice to open the menu to find out whether or not you might be dying (yes, even when your health bar is completely full, you can die in a single mouse click), it's on you to decide to access the menu or not, in order to discover that you're in danger of losing everything. Yes, the UI does not inform you that you could die in the next mouse click. Surprise! Permadeath, 100+ hrs of work deleted in an instant. 

It's your fault, silly. Tsk tsk, you should've been checking the menus!

The game lets you "pass time" and also "go to sleep" while you're bleeding out, and also while you have lacerations, which are wounds that re-open in your sleep. Because there are NO visual indicators on the UI that you're bleeding out, or wounded, you can literally kill yourself by passing time or going to sleep. You did it! It was your choice to unalive yourself, silly! 

The UI is completely bare except for an almost perpetual (always-on, meaningless boy-cried-wolf type of alert[!], for all non-ideal states, such as having the mere risk of potentially getting hypothermia... erm, this goes without saying, it's freaking cold out there). 

I lost 80 hrs of work on Stalker difficulty because I went to sleep for 2 hrs with blood loss, which I did, because.. I didn't know I had blood loss. Nothing on the UI warned me about it.

Continuing with this, it also lets you make the choice to pass time and go to sleep while you're freezing to death, or close to predators. I lost a 70-hr run on the easier Voyageur difficulty because I slept outside in the same area as a (confirmed) single wolf, but a wolf that I had just shot twice in the head with a revolver, and then when struggling with it, stabbed with my knife. It ran away, tail between its legs, yelping, bleeding out, guaranteed to die within 2-3 minutes. Yet, it somehow went over to me and killed me in my sleep before its demise. (FYI - bleeding out wildlife will not track you down to attack you.. so, um, excuse me?)

I've also had shorter runs lost because of this sleeping mechanic as well, sleeping while it's warm, even bundled up, inside, literally in shelter, only for the weather to rapidly change to freezing, and then kill me in my sleep. 

This actually sounds thrilling, right? Going to sleep is the scariest gamble you could do, right?Well, the game forces you to sleep to stay alive, so no, this is simply disrespectful to the player.

For those that don't know - the game saves instantly as things happen, and your saves are instantly deleted as you're dying, not afterward. It's truly brutal. You can't even Alt+F4 to save yourself.

Why would I start over again, spend another 100 hours, only to lose everything when I decide to go to sleep? You've gotta be insane. The Long Dark - after 150 hours, you'll find out that the scariest, most dangerous thing in the treacherous, barren, icy, -60°F Canadian wilderness, filled to the brim with wolves, bears, and cougars, is your very own plush, down-filled sleeping bag.

It would be trivial to add red warnings to the UI, even red icons for the different afflictions, and a flashing red blood drop icon for blood loss (it'll only be on your screen for seconds before you bandage, or minutes before you die), but unfortunately the developers have pursued ambiguity in order to gaslight the player into questioning their sanity after hundreds of hours of labor poured into their runs. An absolute shame.
